title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text:
This document provides an analysis and simulation of the Cumulative Impact Analysis (CIA) process for clean energy projects as proposed by the Office of Environmental Justice and Equity (OEJE). The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.


The first step is to identify the Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of the proposed project. The SGA of a project is defined by the geographic location of the project and its physical footprint, as well as a radius around the project determined by the Energy Facilities Siting Board (EFSB). Table 1 below describes the radii of different energy technologies subject to review for CIA.




Table 1: Specific Geographic Areas for CIA in EFSB Reviews











Energy Technology
Proposed SGA Radius
Rationale




Transmission and Distribution Lines
1/4 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Battery Energy Storage System
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Substation
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Ground-Mounted PV
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Onshore Wind Facility/ Anaerobic Digester > 25MW
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


LNG Facility
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Pipeline
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Fossil Generating Facility
2 miles (non-Major)
5 miles (Major)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Compressor Stations
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations










The Sudbury-Hudson project was an underground transmission line, which would require a 1/4 mile radius around that project.



To determine if the Sudbury-Hudson project is within or near a BA, we examine whether the SGA (including a buffer of the specified radius) overlaps or intersects with “Burdened Areas” (BAs) as identified by the MassEnviroScreen tool. Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. The block group highlighted in red is a BA.








Figure 1




Figure 1 shows that the SGA of the Sudbury-Hudson transmission line intersects with 14 census block groups, including 1 block group designated as BA. Based on guidance, the project would require a CIA.



Using data from MassEnviroScreen, the project applicant must document the values of all the indicators which inform the cumulative impact score. They must highlight all current indicators which exceed the 50th percentile for the specific indicator. This comprehensive inventory establishes the baseline conditions that will be used to assess the project’s incremental impact.
Table 2 shows the MassEnviroScreen indicator values for the Burdened Area within the SGA. Items in red exceed either the statewide 50th percentile, or the 50th percentile for non-Burdened Areas.




Table 2: MassEnviroScreen Indicators for Burdened Area within SGA







Indicator
Raw Value
Statewide Percentile
Exceeds 50th Percentile for non-Burdened Areas?




PM25
6.76

Yes


OZONE

No

No

Yes


PTRAF

No


DWATER

Yes


CancerRisk

No


Respiratory HI
0.23
39.9
No


cleanup_score
20.00
75.2
Yes


gwater_score
18.00
92.7
Yes


BWPScore
3.00
58.7
Yes


SWScore
0.00
0
No


IL_count
5.00
89.3
Yes


High blood pressure among adults
26.70
27.9
No


Coronary heart disease among adults
6.40
46.6
Yes


Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease among adults
6.60
61.2
Yes


Cancer (non-skin) or melanoma among adults
9.00
56.3
No


pedAsthmaPrevalence
13.88
78.8
Yes


BLL
NA
NA
NA


LBW
NA
NA
NA


PMR
233.60

No


HSlesspctE
8.33

Yes


hhburden

Yes

Yes

No


WHPmean
5.11

Yes


pctFldArea
23.84

Yes


Heatmean
418.00
77
Yes













Using the list of relevant, technology-specific indicators established by the EFSB, the project applicant must assess and document the anticipated impact of the proposed project on each indicator within the SGA. The project applicant must determine whether the project will exacerbate any indicator that already exceeds the 50th percentile statewide threshold or cause any additional indicator to exceed the 50th percentile threshold. If either condition is met, the impact is considered a disproportionate adverse effect for that indicator.
Table 3 below lists the key indicators by technology type as identified by the EFSB.




Table 3: Key Indicators by Technology Type







Impact Category

Indicator
Clean Transmission and Distribution
Clean Energy Generation
Clean Energy Storage
Fossil Fuel (Legacy Facilities) - All Types

QUESTIONS:

How do we determine the level of anticipated impact on any indicator?
How do we want to quantify that impact to determine if it creates a




Following the proposed regulations by OEJE, there are two ways to set baseline conditions for determining a disproportionate adverse effect:

comparison against the statewide 50th percentile for a given indicator
comparison against the 50th percentile for non-Burdened Areas

We can explore the significance of these choices by looking at the frequency of 50th percentile exceedances for Burdened Areas in MassEnviroScreen. In other words, how often do Burdened Areas in MassEnviroScreen exceed the 50th percentile when the statewide baseline is used? How often do they exceed the 50th percentile when the baseline is based on non-Burdened Areas?
Table 4 shows statistics on frequency of exceedances using these different baselines. Values indicate the number of exceedances by census block group. For example, using the statewide baseline, the smallest number of exceedances for a burdened area block group is 4 exceedances, and maximum is 27. In comparison, using the non-Burdened Area baseline, the smallest number of exceedances is 6, and the maximum is also 27.




Table 4: MassEnviroScreen Exceedances from Statewide versus non-Burdened Area Baselines






Statistic
Statewide
Non-Burdened Areas

4.0
6.0

18.0

16.4
17.6


stdev
3.4
3.4

15.0

20.0


max
27.0
27.0

The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.


The first step is to identify the Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of the proposed project. Table 1: Specific Geographic Areas for CIA in EFSB Reviews

The Sudbury-Hudson project was an underground transmission line, which would require a 1/4 mile radius around that project.

Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. Figure 1

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text:
This document provides an analysis and simulation of the Cumulative Impact Analysis (CIA) process for clean energy projects as proposed by the Office of Environmental Justice and Equity (OEJE). The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.


The first step is to identify the Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of the proposed project. The SGA of a project is defined by the geographic location of the project and its physical footprint, as well as a radius around the project determined by the Energy Facilities Siting Board (EFSB). Table 1 below describes the radii of different energy technologies subject to review for CIA.




Table 1: Specific Geographic Areas for CIA in EFSB Reviews











Energy Technology
Proposed SGA Radius
Rationale




Transmission and Distribution Lines
1/4 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Battery Energy Storage System
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Substation
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Ground-Mounted PV
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Onshore Wind Facility/ Anaerobic Digester > 25MW
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


LNG Facility
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Pipeline
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Fossil Generating Facility
2 miles (non-Major)
5 miles (Major)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Compressor Stations
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations










The Sudbury-Hudson project was an underground transmission line, which would require a 1/4 mile radius around that project.



To determine if the Sudbury-Hudson project is within or near a BA, we examine whether the SGA (including a buffer of the specified radius) overlaps or intersects with “Burdened Areas” (BAs) as identified by the MassEnviroScreen tool. Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. The block group highlighted in red is a BA.








Figure 1




Figure 1 shows that the SGA of the Sudbury-Hudson transmission line intersects with 14 census block groups, including 1 block group designated as BA. Based on guidance, the project would require a CIA.



Using data from MassEnviroScreen, the project applicant must document the values of all the indicators which inform the cumulative impact score. They must highlight all current indicators which exceed the 50th percentile for the specific indicator. This comprehensive inventory establishes the baseline conditions that will be used to assess the project’s incremental impact.

The Sudbury-Hudson project was an underground transmission line, which would require a 1/4 mile radius around that project.



To determine if the Sudbury-Hudson project is within or near a BA, we examine whether the SGA (including a buffer of the specified radius) overlaps or intersects with “Burdened Areas” (BAs) as identified by the MassEnviroScreen tool. Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. The block group highlighted in red is a BA.








Figure 1




Figure 1 shows that the SGA of the Sudbury-Hudson transmission line intersects with 14 census block groups, including 1 block group designated as BA. Based on guidance, the project would require a CIA.



Using data from MassEnviroScreen, the project applicant must document the values of all the indicators which inform the cumulative impact score. They must highlight all current indicators which exceed the 50th percentile for the specific indicator. This comprehensive inventory establishes the baseline conditions that will be used to assess the project’s incremental impact.
